title: Legendary Patriots kicker Adam Vinatieri elected to Pro Football Hall of Fame
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Adam Vinatieri elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2026, alongside four other players.
Vinatieri is the NFL's all-time scoring leader with 2,673 points, and he made 599 field goals.
He won four Super Bowls, three with the Patriots and one with the Colts, during 24 NFL seasons.

title: Drake Maye loses MVP race to Matthew Stafford by razor-thin margin
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots QB Drake Maye finished second in NFL MVP voting, just one first-place vote behind Rams QB Matthew Stafford.
Stafford led with 366 points and 24 first-place votes, while Maye had 361 points and 23 first-place votes.
The MVP race was the closest since 2003; Stafford topped the league in passing yards and touchdowns.

title: Mike Vrabel named 2025 NFL Coach of the Year
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mike Vrabel wins 2025 NFL Coach of the Year for leading Patriots to Super Bowl in first year as head coach.
Vrabel is among 13 coaches to win NFL Coach of the Year multiple times, previously awarded in 2021 with the Titans.
Patriots finished 2025 season 17-3 under Vrabel, establishing a strong team identity and turnaround from previous seasons.

title: Unlike Tom Brady, Tedy Bruschi has a dog in the Patriots-Seahawks fight
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Tedy Bruschi is openly supporting the Patriots in their Super Bowl LX matchup against the Seahawks.
Tom Brady remains neutral regarding his rooting interests for the Patriots-Seahawks Super Bowl game.
Bruschi cites his friendship with coach Mike Vrabel as a key reason for his support of the Patriots.

title: Pedestrian struck by police cruiser at UMass Lowell, officials say
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A pedestrian was struck by a police cruiser outside UMass Lowell's McGauvran Center on South Campus Thursday evening.
The incident occurred around 6:30 p.m. at the intersection of Wilder and Bachelder streets in Lowell.
Lowell and Massachusetts State Police are investigating; UMass Lowell is providing counseling resources for witnesses.

title: New Bedford police investigate after man goes missing, drowns in harbor
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Jason Vasquez, 51, was found drowned in New Bedford Harbor on Jan. 31, three days after his disappearance.
Vasquez was last seen visiting an adult establishment; he worked at New Bedford Shipyard before his disappearance.
Police are investigating the drowning, with no foul play indicated; Vasquez's vehicle was found at the shipyard.

title: Cambridge brewery workers plan to unionize, file for election
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lamplighter Brewing Co. employees in Cambridge file for a union election with UFCW Local 1445 on Wednesday.
Workers at Lamplighter's two Cambridge locations seek representation to ensure their perspectives are considered in the evolving industry.
UFCW Local 1445 currently represents 11,000 workers in Massachusetts across various industries including retail and food processing.

title: Patriots OC Josh McDaniels named AP Assistant Coach of the Year
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Josh McDaniels named AP Assistant Coach of the Year at NFL Honors in San Francisco.
Under McDaniels, Patriots' offense improved from third-lowest to second-highest scoring in one season.
McDaniels on third stint with Patriots; hesitant about future head coaching opportunities.

title: Patriots, Seahawks both have defensive starters missing from practice
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots linebacker Harold Landry did not participate in practice due to a lingering knee injury ahead of Super Bowl LX.
Patriots linebacker Robert Spillane was upgraded to limited participation with an ankle injury and remains crucial for the defense.
Seahawks rookie safety Nick Emmanwori missed practice because of an ankle injury, but Seattle expects him to play.

title: NY man allegedly stole $325K in seafood from Worcester warehouse in 1 of several heists
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Romoy Forbes, 31, from Deer Park, N.Y., is charged with stealing seafood, blueberries, and cologne worth over $758,000.
Forbes allegedly hacked email accounts of trucking carriers to book and divert shipments intended for legitimate customers.
He faces up to 10 years in prison for interstate theft charges and is part of an FBI investigation into national cargo thefts.
